ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Developed more grammatical understanding of the Italian language and significant cultural accomplishments - films, books, cities, etc.
I continued developing skills in reading, writing, and grammar.
We covered the second half of the introduction to italian book. We learned new vocabulary as well as verb tenses and sentence structure.
I furthered my understanding of Italian grammar, learned a lot more vocabulary, and improved my speaking skills through the daily conversations and oral presentation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - great accommodating teachers and engagement of the class; great language class to fulfill the requirement
Weaknesses - somewhat unclear with what is to be expected in the course/assignments/etc.

I think that this course was good and has the potential to be really really good if there's a little bit more time for the professor to get familiar with it. I think that the two weeks where we did not have a professor in the beginning of the semester was a little bit hard to recover from, but I think that considering all of the factors, it was a great class and I learned a decent amount. The only thing I would say is that I think she was a bit flustered/disorganized from being assimilated to the teaching environment at Yale so quickly so it was a bit all over the place.
I really liked the structure of the class. I like how it was the same book and a very similar structure which continued off first semester (ITAL 110).

I think uniformity across this course's instruction would have been helpful. In italian 110, each course moved at roughly the same pace and completed the same assignments, but this seemed to range across classes, and made it difficult to plan work. This section in particular seemed to operate very differently than others, which was hard when the syllabus in terms of exams was still followed. Keeping up with the same assignments etc might have been helpful when it came time for standardized exams.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!! The Italian department is incredibly accommodating and it's a fun language to fulfill your requirement.
Definitely! I think that this class is a great language requirement class and does a really good job of getting you comfortable with learning the language in a nice way.
Yes. I absolutely love the language and the culture. Everyone in my class was engaged and all of the professors are kind.

I think Italian is an interesting language to use to fulfill the requirement at Yale. That being said, more opportunities for speaking and writing outside of the tests, as well as more cultural education would be appreciated.
Definitely! If you are interested in the Italian language and culture, this course is perfect.
